We are working with a dataset from a czech bank. 

Below we have loaded all the packages and data as well as organized and sturctured it so we can work with it.
loading all packages and data
```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)
library(ggmosaic)
library(ggalluvial)
library(rpart)
library(rpart.plot)
library(gridExtra)
library(usethis)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
```

```{r}

account <- read.csv('./account.csv', sep = ";")
card <- read.csv('./card.csv', sep = ";")
client <- read.csv('./client.csv', sep = ";")
disp <- read.csv('./disp.csv', sep = ";")
district <- read.csv('./district.csv', sep = ';')
loan <- read.csv('./loan.csv', sep = ";")
order <- read.csv('./order.csv', sep = ";")
trans <- read.csv('./trans.csv', sep = ";")

```

clean/organize account
```{r}

#reformat date
account$date_ymd <- format(as.Date(as.character(account$date), "%y%m%d"), "19%y/%m/%d") 

account <- account %>%
  select(-date)

#factorize variables
account <- account %>% 
  mutate (frequency = as_factor(frequency), 
          date_ymd = as.Date(date_ymd)
          ) %>%
  mutate(frequency = case_when(
    frequency == 'POPLATEK MESICNE' ~ 'monthly issuance',
    frequency == 'POPLATEK TYDNE' ~ 'weekly issuance',
    frequency == 'POPLATEK PO OBRATU' ~ 'issuance after transaction'
  ))

```

clean/organize card
```{r}

#reformat date
card$issued_date <- format(as.Date(as.character(card$issued), "%y%m%d"), "19%y/%m/%d")

#factorize variables
card <- card %>%
  mutate(type = as_factor(type), 
         issued_date = as.Date(issued_date)
         )
  
```

clean/organize district

clean/organize loan

clean/organize order

         k_symbol = as_factor(k_symbol)
         )

    k_symbol == 'POJISTNE' ~ 'issurance payment',

clean/organize trans
```{r}

#reformat date
trans$date_dmy <- format(as.Date(as.character(trans$date), "%y%m%d"), "19%y/%m/%d")

trans <- trans %>%
  select(-date)

#factorize variables
trans <- trans %>%
  mutate(type = as_factor(type),
         operation = as_factor(operation),
         k_symbol = as_factor(k_symbol),
         date_dmy = as.Date(date_dmy)
         )

trans <- trans %>%
  mutate(type = case_when(
    type == 'PRIJEM' ~ 'credit',
    type == 'VYDAJ' ~ 'withdrawal',
    type == 'VYBER' ~ 'withdrawal in cash'
  )) %>%
  mutate(operation = case_when(
    operation == 'VYBER KARTOU' ~ 'credit card withdrawal',
    operation == 'VKLAD' ~ 'credit in cash',
    operation == 'PREVOD Z UCTU' ~ 'collection from other bank',
    operation == 'VYBER' ~ 'withdrawal in cash',
    operation == 'PREVOD NA UCET' ~ 'remittance to other bank'
  )) %>%
  mutate(k_symbol = case_when(
    k_symbol == 'POJISTNE' ~ 'insurrance payment',
    k_symbol == 'SLUZBY' ~ 'payment for statement',
    k_symbol == 'UROK' ~ 'interest credited',
    k_symbol == 'SIPO' ~ 'hosehold',
    k_symbol == 'DUCHOD' ~ 'old-age pension',
    k_symbol == 'UVER' ~ 'loan payment'
  ))


```

Join tables:
1) Left join of account with disp to df_account_disp. Then left join df_account_disp with client to df_account_disp_client. 
```{r}
df_account_disp <- left_join(account, disp, by = 'account_id') 
df_account_disp_client <- left_join(df_account_disp, client, by = 'client_id') %>%
  select(-birth_number, -birthday) %>%
  rename(
    district_account = district_id.x,
    date_account = date_ymd,
    district_client = district_id.y,
  )
```

2) Left join order with df_account_disp_client to df_order_account_client_disp.
```{r}
df_order_account_client_disp <- left_join(order, df_account_disp_client, by = "account_id")
```

3) Left join loan with df_account_disp_client to df_loan_account_client_disp.
```{r}
df_loan_account_client_disp <- left_join(loan, df_account_disp_client, by = "account_id")
```

4) Left join trans with df_account_disp_client to df_trans_account_client_disp.
```{r}
df_trans_account_client_disp <- left_join(trans, df_account_disp_client, by = "account_id") %>%
  rename(
    trans_type = type.x,
    account_type = type.y
  )
```

Visualize the number of accounts according to the clients age with different kinds of bar charts
```{r}
#bar chart, one bar for each age
df_account_disp_client %>% ggplot(aes(x = age)) + geom_bar() + scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Paired") 

#bar chart, women and men separated, one bar for each age
df_account_disp_client %>% ggplot(aes(x = age, fill = gender)) + geom_bar(position = 'dodge') +
         scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Paired") + xlab('Age of clients')

#stacked bar chart, women and men separated, one bar for each age
df_account_disp_client %>% ggplot(aes(x = age, fill = gender)) + geom_bar() +
         scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Paired") + xlab('Age of clients')

#two bar charts, women and men separated, each age one bar
df_account_disp_client %>% ggplot(aes(x = age, fill = gender)) + geom_bar() +
         scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Paired") + facet_wrap(~ gender) + xlab('Age of clients')

#coordination flipped bar chart, omen and men separated, one bar for each age
df_account_disp_client %>% ggplot(aes(x = age, fill = gender)) + geom_bar() + coord_flip() +
         scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Paired") + xlab('Age of clients')

#coordination flipped bar chart, omen and men separated, one bar for each age, in percentage
df_account_disp_client %>% ggplot(aes(x = age, fill = gender)) + geom_bar(position = 'fill') +
  coord_flip() + geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, color = 'red', size = 0.75) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Paired") + xlab('Age of clients')

```

Group the clients same sized age groups. The group size is 16. With grouping the clients we are losing some information. But with grouping the clients in different group sizes we would create a misleading chart. 
```{r}
#order the clients by youngest and oldest, youngest is 10, oldest is 86
#group all the clients in 7 different groups
df_account_disp_client <- df_account_disp_client %>%
  mutate(age_grouped = case_when(
    age <= 16 ~ '1-16',
    age <= 32 ~ '17-32',
    age <= 48 ~ '33-48',
    age <= 64 ~ '49-64',
    age <= 72 ~ '65-72',
    age <= 86 ~ '73-86',
    TRUE ~ 'not known'
  ))

#factor the groups
df_account_disp_client <- df_account_disp_client %>% 
  mutate(age_grouped = as_factor(age_grouped))

#order the new age column in a determined way
df_account_disp_client$age_grouped <- 
  ordered(df_account_disp_client$age_grouped, levels = c('1-16', '17-32', '33-48', '49-64', '65-72',
                                                         '73-86'))
```

Analyse how many accounts are duplicates
```{r}
nrow(account)

#create data frame duplicate_accounts and print all of those
duplicate_accounts <- df_account_disp_client[duplicated(df_account_disp_client$account_id)|duplicated(df_account_disp_client$account_id, fromLast=TRUE),]
duplicate_accounts

#number of accounts with more than one client
dim(df_account_disp_client[duplicated(df_account_disp_client$account_id),])[1]

#is there an account with more than 2 clients?
table_dup_accounts <- table(duplicate_accounts$account_id)
most_dup_accounts <- names(table_dup_accounts[table_dup_accounts==max(table_dup_accounts)])
#we see, that it is a 1x869 matrix and the number of duplicate accounts is 869 aswell
#so there isn't an account with more than two clients connected

#create data frame unique_accounts with just one client behind
unique_accounts <- anti_join(df_account_disp_client, duplicate_accounts)
unique_accounts
```
ANALYSIS: The clients seem to be partners because there is always a men and a women of the same age (+- 10 years)
